title: BAM to present Actors' 'Glory of the World'
text:
BAM to present Actors''Glory of the World' Elizabeth Kramer , @arts_bureau 2:25 p.m. EDT October 21, 2015 Video | CJ's Elizabeth Kramer previews Humana Festival play "The Glory of the World." The cast of Charles Mee's "The Glory of the World" directed by Les Waters for Actors Theatre of Louisville's 2015 Humana Festival of New American Plays. (Photo: Bill Brymer. Courtesy Actors Theatre of Louisville.) 
Actors Theatre of Louisville will present “The Glory of The World” by Charles Mee and directed by Les Waters at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Jan. 16 through Feb. 6. 
The play premiered in this year’s Humana Festival of New American Plays in recognition of the centennial of the birth of Thomas Merton — the Catholic monk, mystic and author of more than 70 books, including the 1948 bestselling autobiography “The Seven Storey Mountain.” 
Merton, made his home at the Abbey of Gethsemani in Bardstown, Ky., from 1941 until his death in 1968. Review | 'Glory of the World' powerful 
The official opening in New York is slated for Jan. 21 with previews scheduled for Jan. 16, 19 and 20. 
Instead of recounting Merton’s life, the characters in “The Glory of The World” are at a birthday party for Merton where they discover that many have vastly different interpretations of who he was and, as if in a serious contest, compete to impress each other with their knowledge of the man. 
Actors Theatre said Waters will reprise his role as a man who appears and is mostly silent onstage at the beginning and the end of the play during preview and opening performances. Singer-songwriter Will Oldham , also known as Bonnie “Prince” Billy, will play the role in the remaining performances. 
The cast of Charles Mee's "The Glory of the World" directed by Les Waters for Actors Theatre of Louisville's 2015 Humana Festival of New American Plays. (Photo: Bill Brymer. Courtesy Actors Theatre of Louisville.) 
The production is receiving support from Knight Blanc , an entity based in Knoxville, Tenn., and associated with Roy Cockrum, a theater veteran who won the Powerball lottery last year and has granted money to theater including Chicago’s Goodman Theatre and Steppenwolf Theatre. 
Earlier this year, Actors Theatre announced that it is receiving a $1.2 million grant from The Roy Cockrum Foundation to support of its Apprentice/Intern Company. 
This announcement of this New York run of “The Glory of the World” comes as Lucas Hnath ’s “The Christians” is being performed at New York’s Playwrights Horizons with Waters directing. Humana Festival play ‘The Christians’ tests rigors of faith 
He also directed “The Christians” for its premiere at the 2014 Humana Festival. In September, this off-Broadway production, which had opened in August, received an extended run through Oct. 25. That cast includes original cast members Emily Donahoe, Andrew Garman, Larry Powell and Linda Powell. 
Like “The Christians,” the New York production of Mee’s play “The Glory of the World” also includes many members of the original cast. The cast includes Eric Berryman (Roland), Ryan Bourque (Arnold), Andrew Garman (Benny), Aaron Lynn (Robert), Bruce McKenzie (Albert), Barney O’Hanlon (Bobby), Conrad Schott (Conrad), David Ryan Smith (Cameron), and Cameron Benoit, Josh Bonzie, John Ford-Dunker, José Leon, Joe Lino, Max Monnig, Collin Morris, Brian Muldoon, Blake Russell and Lorenzo Villanueva as Ensemble. 
“The Glory of the World” marks a return to working partnership between Mee and Waters at Actors Theatre and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In 2000, the theater’s Humana Festival premiered Mee’s “Big Love,” updating of Aeschylus’ “The Supplicant Women,” with Waters directing. The play also was part of the academy’s 2001 New Wave Festival.
